assessments.task_description:
The Research Methods Learning Journal is a reflective assessment designed to support your ongoing engagement with course content and to encourage the gradual development of your understanding of research design, methodology, and ethical practice in Applied Linguistics. Across the semester, you are required to submit five short reflective journal entries, each based on a selected session of the course. Each entry should be between 100 and 200 words in length and is worth 3 per cent of the final grade, contributing a total of 15 per cent.

PURPOSE

The purpose of this assessment is to promote regular reflection on your learning and to support you in connecting theoretical discussions of research methods to your own developing research interests. Through these reflections, you will consolidate your understanding of research design, identify areas of uncertainty, and consider how different methodological approaches may be applied to empirical research in Applied Linguistics.

CONTENT

Each journal entry should reflect on your learning from a particular session of the course and engage meaningfully with the content covered. You may consider what you learned about research methods or research design during that session, which methodological approaches or analytical techniques were introduced, what aspects you found challenging or unclear, and how the concepts discussed could inform the design of a research project in Applied Linguistics. Not all aspects need to be addressed in every entry; rather, entries should demonstrate thoughtful, reflective, and substantive engagement with the session content.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. Whilst students may use generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies to support their preparation, such use must be appropriately acknowledged or referenced in line with UQ’s academic integrity expectations. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Over the course of the semester, students are required to submit five Research Methods Learning Journal entries.

assessments.task_description:
The In-Class Presentation requires you to work in groups of two to four students to deliver an in-class presentation based on an assigned chapter from Research Methods in Applied Linguistics (Phakiti & Paltridge, Eds.), accompanied by an individual reflective submission. The task is designed to deepen your engagement with research methods content, enhance your academic communication skills, and encourage critical reflection on methodological choices and issues in Applied Linguistics research.

PURPOSE

This assessment evaluates your ability to understand, synthesise, and communicate research methods knowledge, as well as to reflect critically on your own learning. While the presentation component focuses on collaborative engagement with course material, the reflective component ensures that all students demonstrate individual understanding and meaningful engagement with the methodological issues discussed.

PRESENTATION

Each group will deliver a 20 to 30-minute in-class presentation on an assigned chapter that complements, but does not duplicate, the tutorial reading for that week. Presentations will be scheduled between Weeks 4 and 12. The presentation should provide a clear and coherent overview of the chapter’s key concepts, research approaches, and methodological insights, and should include a short in-class activity designed to actively engage peers with the content. Presentations will be delivered in class and recorded for moderation purposes.

REFLECTIVE COMMENTARY

Following the presentation, students are required to submit a 400-word individual reflective commentary. This submission must include a reflective commentary on what was learned from the group presentation. The reflection should engage with the content of the presentation and the process of working together, highlight key insights or challenges, and consider how the content may inform the student’s own research interests or proposal.

assessments.task_description:
This assessment requires you to submit a written research proposal of 2,000 words (not counting references or appendices) outlining the design, rationale, and significance of an original research project in Applied Linguistics. The proposal represents the culmination of your learning in the course and provides an opportunity to demonstrate your ability to conceptualize, design, and critically evaluate a feasible research study.

PURPOSE

This assessment evaluates your ability to define a research problem, engage critically with relevant literature and theory, formulate a clear research question, design an appropriate and ethical methodology, and reflect on the feasibility, limitations, and contribution of your proposed study.

STRUCTURE

The proposal should begin with an introduction that outlines the research topic, establishes its relevance within Applied Linguistics, and provides an overview of the proposal structure. This should be followed by a literature review that synthesises relevant research, identifies key theoretical perspectives, and motivates the research focus. The proposal should then clearly state the research question or hypothesis and justify it in relation to the literature. The methodology section should describe the proposed research design, including context, participants where relevant, data collection methods, and data analysis procedures, and should demonstrate that the proposed approach is ethical, appropriate, and feasible. The proposal should conclude with a critical reflection on the significance, limitations, and anticipated challenges of the study. A complete reference list in APA 7 format must be included.

STATEMENT ON AI & MT

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) tools and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies to support their preparation, such use must be appropriately acknowledged or referenced in line with UQ’s academic integrity expectations. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

Successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. Indeed, to pass this assessment, students are required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission during a follow-up one-on-one interview independent of AI and MT tools. The interview will be conducted live (in person or via Zoom), and the use of generative AI or MT tools will therefore not be permitted during the interview itself. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.submission_guidelines: The Research Proposal must be submitted via Turnitin as a single Word or PDF file. The proposal must not exceed 2,000 words, excluding references, and must adhere to APA 7 formatting and referencing conventions.

assessments.task_description:
This In-person Oral Interview is a mandatory, identity verified assessment that functions as an academic integrity hurdle. Students who do not pass this interview will fail the course, regardless of their performance in other assessments.

FORMAT & TIMING

The interview will be conducted in person during Exam Weeks 1 and 2. Each interview will take approximately ten minutes. Students will sign up for an interview time with the course coordinator or a tutor and will be required to present valid student identification. Interviews will be recorded in accordance with university policy on the recording of oral assessments.

PURPOSE

The interview provides an opportunity for students to reflect on their learning experience in the course and to demonstrate conceptual understanding of research methods in Applied Linguistics. Students will be asked to discuss their Research Proposal, including the rationale for their research question, key methodological decisions, ethical considerations, and anticipated challenges. The interview also serves to confirm the authenticity and authorship of submitted assessment work.
